required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Copper Intrauterine Device (IUD) Insertion at Cesarean Delivery
clinical_study.official_title: Transcesarean IUD Insertion: A Prospective Cohort Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Inc.

clinical_study.source: Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Inc.

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the expulsion rates of copper Intrauterine Devices (IUDs) placed at time of Cesarean Delivery.

detailed_description.textblock: This was a prospective clinical study with 90 patients undergoing cesarean section. After delivery of the placenta, a ParaGardÂ® copper T380A IUD was inserted through the hysterotomy site. IUD placement was confirmed by visualization of the strings at the cervical os or via ultrasound at the 6 week postpartum visit. Subjects also received a phone call 6 months after IUD placement to ascertain physician follow-up and patient satisfaction. This telephone call was to ensure that each subject attended her postpartum visit, had an evaluation of IUD placement and then we performed a survey. This survey used a Likert Scale to measure each subject's satisfaction. The fields included very satisfied, satisfied, somewhat satisfied, neutral, somewhat unsatisfied, unsatisfied and very unsatisfied.

primary_outcome.description: Expulsion of IUDs placed at time of cesarean delivery

secondary_outcome.description: Satisfaction of subjects who received an IUD at time of cesarean delivery will be measured with the Likert Scale.

intervention.intervention_name: Copper IUD placement at time Cesarean Delivery (Copper T 380A)
intervention.description: Placement of Paragard IUD at time of Cesarean Delivery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- singleton gestation
- greater than 35 weeks gestation
- speaks English or Spanish
- desires IUD for contraception
- undergoing a cesarean delivery
Exclusion Criteria:
- evidence of chorioamnionitis
- history of chlamydia within this pregnancy

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Inc.
